Just came back to this review after a few hours of having cooled off.  I wrote my original review right after rage quitting, which wasn't fair to the game. I'm changing my oppinion on it, but I'm leaving what I wrote before, because I think some of the complaints and feelings have merit.

As a tldr foreword, I'd rate this game as flawed, but worth playing.

Sound and art are excellent, level design is hit and miss, and combat can make the game a slog at times.  A more detailed review is below.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

What went right-  Again, the aesthetic is just gorgeous.  I love the accuracy of the setting, and the voice acting is superb.  I think I would have liked to have heard the voice actress display more emotional range, such as having dialogue other than backstory and grunts, but I recognize how that could be difficult to implement.  While I see how this could have been a turn off for some, I actually really appreciate that the dialogue is in icelandic.  I assume it's Icelandic, anyway.

What went wrong-  I still think the combat system could use some work.  There're two main gripes I have here.

First is mobility.  Without using Freya's Speed, you move painfully slow in relation to the Jotun. While this isn't always a huge deal, as I said before, in 3/6 fights it makes a huge difference. The dodge roll is also kind of an issue, for two reasons.  First, depending on the frame of the swing animation, the dodge roll comes in a bit late as a cancel, which makes the game feel less responsive.  Second, the distance is pretty short considering the huge size of the Jotun.

The second issue is the combat mechanics. The major issue with these is tutorialization. Until it was pointed out, I didn't know that projectiles could be attacked, or that Freya's Speed sped up combat animations. Aside from tutorialization, a couple of the boss fights suffer from both too little player communication, and too much stagnant AOE.

By player communication, I mean animation and environment cues to the player. For example, when a boss in dark souls might hold up a sword for a second before swinging, letting the player know he/she needs to dodge. In a few of the fights these cues seem too short to reliably get out of the way, or don't give enough directional information to understand where to dodge.

By stagnant AOE I mean that sections of the combat space are made too dangerous to stay in, with effects lasting longer than they should. Since spaces of the map are made dangerous, sometimes even with proper player response to animation cues it becomes impossible to dodge an attack.

In conclusion, better tutorialization of mechanics would have drastically effected playabillity, while certain combat mechanics could have been implemented better.  I feel for example, that cooldown timers may have been a better idea than limited uses of powers, as after you use all your powers in a fight, it becomes nearly impossible to complete.  This would also have allowed stricter control of fight pacing.  Lastly, a Restart" option in the menu would have been a godsend

Jotun is an action adventure indie game developed by Thunder Lotus Studios where you play as Thora, a fallen viking warrior who must impress the Gods in order to reach Valhalla. Positives:
-The attention to detail is incredible! 99% of this game looks like it was hand drawn by brilliant artists because it was
-Visually stunning, the establishing shots that are scattered throughout the different areas really makes you feel like you're part of a bigger, more mystical, world
-The music is awesome; epic and intense when appropriate and ominous when it needs to be, and very well composed with action-sensitive crossfades so you're never taken out of your immersion
-The gameplay is as solid as a rock with plenty of variety of puzzles, terrain, level design, power ups, and enemies
-The hit detection is excellent. You never take damage unless you should take damage and the enemies get the same treatment. If you want to beat this game and are having trouble, just get good.
-The difficulty is pretty high in some parts, but fairly forgiving with deaths. As it should be in an action-adventure game.

Negatives:
-In the first area (Niflheim) Yggdrassil's roots are very pixelated. This is the only time in the game that I've seen this and I'm surprised it got past the alpha stage. Not really a big deal, it just looks weird.
-When you stand behind something it's difficult to see yourself. You can still see Thora's silhouette, but in the darker areas you can get lost for a few seconds, which is a bit annoying. If your silhouette was a bit brighter when you walked behind something(light gray instead of dark gray) it would remedy this
-The map is great, but Thora's current position doesn't appear on it. It's not too difficult to figure out where you are, but it slows down the gameplay everytime you consult your map and need to double check your surroundings. Especially in a game that encourages exploration.


Overall I would highly recommend this to anyone who likes adventuring, Norse mythology, and a combination of both. Also to the gamers out there looking for a challenge, the bosses in this game DO NOT JOKE AROUND. Be prepared to get owned a few times, I sure as hell know I did. Get this game if you are looking for a unique experience, with a very artsy feeling and some interesting difficulty levels. Be prepared for the level with fire giants to potentially ruin your enjoyment of the game however, as it is a really high difficulty spike compared to the rest of the game.

It is the boss battles where I had most trouble with. Bosses tend to move great distances, and then stay static so that you can catch up. I get confused selecting one of the seven powers and using them (select through two buttons, use with another one), so I ended up not using them efficiently. Because of all that, the boss battles drag longer than expected, thus making me frustrated whenever I fail to impress the gods.

There is one, the fire giant, that is supposed to be harder than the rest, as the developer stated in the forums. It becomes easier to beat whenever you can spam enough powers. And those are the small things that pile up into this non recommendation.

To those self aggrandizing cultural stalwarts who are - I present to you Jotun, the latest in an exponentially increasing list of beautifully crafted indie darlings that strengthen the art argument just about monthly.\nJotun's story is that of our heroine, a viking woman named Thora, who's life ends unceremoniously in a storm. Unable to ascend unto the halls of Valhalla, Thora must garner the reverence of the Norse gods to secure her rightful place in Asgard, all the while revealing the story of her life in pieces along the way. reviewText: Beautiful and Brief

First impressions: beautifuly animated and graphical game. The story is wonderful. The feel, the play, so simple yet challenging. Quite reminiscent of Shadow of the Colossus, a favourite of mine. Totally recommend this game!

Jotun is a beautifully hand-drawn game which was funded through a very successful Kickstarter campaign. In Jotun, you must prove yourself to the Norse Gods by solving puzzles in notible mythological locations until some of them desire to challenge you themselves.

Exploration in Jotun is not action-packed, and is rather a little bit on the slower side. Thora (the female warrior you play as) moves at a somewhat slow pace, but in my experience, it greatly helped the atmospheric effect that each individual area provided by making me slow down and take in the sights. There are some incredibly impressive locations that you can see through the game's preview screenshot showcase that give you a slight glimpse into how beautifully drawn the game actually is.

In Jotun, ingame progression is based off finishing areas in a hub world. From the biginning of the game, you can choose your own path to go. Each corner has two levels and a boss. The boss door is locked and requires two Runes to open. Each of the two levels in a corner has its own individual Rune. After finding the two Runes in a corner, the God who oversees that location will allow you to challenge them and attempt to prove your worth.

With a few exceptions, the game revolves around mostly solving puzzles until you collect a specific area's Rune. While venturing through locations to find Runes, you may find hidden collectables. They come in the form of Golden Apples, which are permanent health increases, and God Spells, activated abilities that give you a temporary power up. Each level in a corner has one Golden Apple and one God Spell. It's possible to complete the game without finding any of these, but for someone such as myself who enjoys to find and do everything possible, it did make my experience quite a bit easier.

When it comes to Jotun's bosses, I never felt a sense of I'm just not powerful enough for this." The game itself when it comes to combat is reminiscent of a Souls game. You have a dodge roll
date: and bosses are more of an endurance run than a sprint. This means that you're having to dodge quite a few projectiles and telegraphed attacks that are only possible by dodge rolling. I did feel that in almost every situation that it wouldn't have been a bad decision to increase Thora's movement speed
recommended: but it mostly just comes down to feeling the game out and improving your own gameplay. It's a refreshing feeling compared to other adventure games.\n\nI would highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in a somewhat slow paced adventure and puzzle solving game that has a Norse mythology setting. With an above average boss difficulty

A short but beautiful game.  It is at its strongest when it centers on exploration and puzzle-solving, but its reliance on randomness added to the world's threats subtracts from the experience.

This game is beautifully designed, with every frame very clearly hand-drawn at a level I would expect from a golden age Disney cartoon.  For the main character, most of your enemies, and the scenery, this works phenomenally.  I did notice some choppiness to the animation in two of the bosses, but in all the style works to the game's credit.

This game starts off deceptively simple, but quickly ramps up the difficulty.  There is very little handholding involved, but they make sure you understand a mechanic before they will let you progress.  New powers are not given, they are earned through exploration, though admittedly the shrines that give them are fairly easy to find once you realize the pause menu has a map on it.  When you earn a power, there is no text that explains it, the game instead opts to demonstrate its use.

Throughout the game, Thora will occasionally give a voice-over explaining an aspect of Norse mythology, or the story of her own life.  With the exception of one level, this is well-executed, not seeming overbearing and taking place while still giving you control, allowing you to progress as she speaks, if you wish.  I did feel that the swamp level overdid it, its puzzle being to make you traverse the level to reconstruct the creation myth, but this is a small gripe.

The game's biggest struggles lie in its mechanics.  The strong attack is nearly useless, save for puzzle solving.  By my observations, it does precisely the same damage as if you just hammered the light attack for the same span of time, with the added drawback of rendering you immobile for a rediculously long period of time, praying no one around you hits you and interupts the attack.  The isometric view makes for beautiful landscapes, but hit boxes, particularly for bosses, tend to vary wildly.  In one move, a boss' entire body will be a solid object, allowing Thora to hit him even if she swings for his head which should be far above her.  In another move on the same boss, Thora will have to walk under him, swinging at his ankles again.

By far what prompted the most swearing from me, however, was its random elements.  You may be getting your powers from the Norse gods, but you will spend most of the game praying to RNGesus.  Many of the environmental dangers run off of RNG, such as random lightning strikes in a cloud level, and the bosses seem to choose from their skill sets at random.  This tends to lead to the Dark Souls problem of repeatedly throwing oneself at a boss fight, praying they don't use the one move that wrecks your face quite so often this time.

In all, though, a very enjoyable game, and one I am happy to have bought and supported.

Jotun succeeds strongly and wholistically in relating a memorable overview of Norse mythology while weaving and foiling that with a woman's personal narrative in that culture.
Nothing feels superfluous. There exist independently gamey elements, but they seem to have been chosen and work perfectly for just exactly what they're chosen to do.

The visuals are clean and emotive with camera panning conveying strong vistas and a sense of scope while the main character's animation feels smooth and just the right amount of visually off to place her as outsider on this ethereal plane of beings.

Sound design is epically rumbly and deep, establishing weight and import to the right objects and events.

The game pacing works right along with that visual scope. It is plodding and deliberate. You feel small and alone against enormous beings. Your motions and attacks feel slow but powerful; that is your connection to this place.
Huge sections of world are effectively empty - Punctuated by the appearance of powerful forces and rare monstrous beings. (For real, one third or less of the levels have any actual enemies to fight besides bosses.)

I could probably start running in circles describing how one elements leads into or support the other, but it should be clear by now that this was a fun, engaging experience with Norse myths. If you want to spend a few hours living the legends, jump in.

The possible cons that some gamers should consider:
1. Short (Think twice if you're the bro always asking for X hours out of each gaming dollar spent.)
2. Easy (I think all the exploration and combat fits perfectly to tell the story and theme, but the slow, deliberate fights are mechanically trivial.)

Jotun is an isometric action game where you play as a viking woman who has died at sea. Because her death wasn't honourable she has to prove herself to the gods by defeating the Jotun in combat.

The game's art style and sound design are both fantastic and do wonders for setting a tone in the world as well as the various Jotun fights. The combat is slow and feels very deliberate when executed. This makes fighting the giant Jotun feel like it has a better sense of scale. You feel as if you are this tiny person fighting this formidable giant who is much stronger than you.

The thing I liked the best about Jotun is that it teaches you almost all of the mechanics required for the bosses organically in the exploration phases prior to the actual boss fights. You are given an environment to learn and practice in, so when you eventually get to the Jotun there are no surprises. I say almost because there is a mechanic in one fight that isn't introduced prior to said fight. Not sure if I missed something, but that aisde Jotun does an excellent job of introducing and teaching the player through playing the game.

Jotun is a beautiful game that is mechanically sound and prefers to teach it's players through it's design. I think it is a fantastic game and if anything I've said here has you interested I would recommend picking it up.
